I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is working together with the nations of Southeast 
Asia1 to prepare a regional cooperation strategy and program (RCSP). The work entails three 
main challenges.  First, the strategy must be built on a foundation of rigorous analysis of the 
potential gains from regional cooperation. Economic analysis is needed to identify the specific 
sectors and projects in which transnational approaches add the most value.   Second, the role 
of ADB in supporting regional cooperation needs to be clearly defined, based on ADB’s ability to 
add value to the structures and initiatives that are already in place.  Third, the strategy must be 
built around concrete interventions aimed at two key goals: building regional competitiveness to 
establish a foundation for sustainable economic growth, and reducing poverty in the region, 
particularly in areas that are distant from national centers.  On various occasions since 2003, 
the key underpinnings of the envisaged strategy have been discussed with the governments 
that will be involved in the RCSP.  During these discussions it was agreed that extensive 
consultations be held during the preparation and implementation of the new strategy to receive 
needed inputs and to confirm counterpart commitment.  To accelerate the preparation of the 
strategy,  ADB  proposes  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  provide  the  most  current  analytical 
assessment of a number of possible themes of the strategy and to support the consultation 
process, including a high-level forum on regional cooperation in Southeast Asia.2   
II.  ISSUES  
2.  The nations of Southeast Asia are linked by a distinct geography and by a dramatic 
economic history, including the severe financial crisis in 1997.  During the last decade, a broad 
awareness of common economic and social challenges has fuelled an increasing number of 
major cooperation initiatives at regional, subregional, and bilateral levels.  Most recently, the 
summit of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), held in October 2003 in Bali, 
Indonesia, called for the establishment of an ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) in 2020.3  
3.  ASEAN envisages the AEC as a single market and production base, to firmly establish 
Southeast  Asia  as  a  dynamic  competitor  in  the  world  economy.  A  recent  ASEAN 
competitiveness study4 concluded that the greatest obstacle to competitiveness in the region is 
the fragmentation of the market, which sharply increases the cost of doing business in the 
region and deters foreign direct investment.  To overcome this fragmentation and realize the 
ambitious AEC vision, the nations of the region will have to surmount a number of obstacles. 
Among the most difficult of these are the infrastructure challenges posed by its archipelagic 
geography.    This  unusual  landscape  requires  integrated  planning  of  transport  and  energy 
infrastructure, as many areas are far more easily linked to other nations than they are to their 
own national centers.  Infrastructure issues are especially serious barriers to development in the 
poorer, border islands of Indonesia and the Philippines, and in Sarawak and Sabah in Malaysia.

4.  Transport has long been a focus in regional cooperation in Southeast Asia, as reflected 
in the initiatives of the ASEAN transportation network. In the recent ASEAN Summit in October 
2003,  the  need  to  further  develop  land,  air,  and  sea  linkages  was  again  emphasized,  in 
anticipation of greater cross-border movement of goods and services with the implementation of 
ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA) and other ASEAN+3 initiatives.  An integrated approach to 
transport development in the region, based on analysis and projections of regional demand for 
transport services under different scenarios and on a study of the alternative options for meeting 
that demand, is required to ensure that investments are prioritized correctly.  
5.  Energy sector development to meet the rapidly growing demand in Southeast Asia also 
requires integrated planning, as efficient resource development necessitates a regional, not 
local, perspective. This is particularly significant in the context of the regional integration effort in 
the electricity and gas sectors, as highlighted in the ASEAN Power Grid (APG) and the Trans 
ASEAN Gas Pipeline (TAGP) programs and the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) 
Asian Gas Grid program.  A recent study by the Institute of Energy Economics of Japan projects 
that energy consumption in Asia will increase annually by 3.8%, and the gas share of this 
growing amount will increase from the current 7% to 14% by 2010.5 A new strategy for regional 
cooperation in Southeast Asia will have to place a high priority on helping individual nations 
develop their energy sectors in a more coordinated and synchronized way. 
6.  To help meet these and other challenges ADB is currently working with the concerned 
stakeholders to formulate its first RCSP for Southeast Asia.  ADB’s efforts will review and 
selectively build on, streamline, and integrate past and ongoing assistance activities in the 
region, including investments in infrastructure development and TA activities in support of the 
Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Philippines-East ASEAN Growth Area (BIMP-
EAGA).  Such an effort will advance the core development themes of the AEC to make ASEAN 
a more dynamic and competitive segment of the global supply chain.  While the East ASEAN 
Growth Area is expected to be one key area of new activities, this strategy is expected to review 
and reformulate ADB assistance in that region in the context of overall regional cooperation 
opportunities in Southeast Asia. 
7.  ADB  has  already  consulted  with  key  international  organizations  that  are  supporting 
Southeast Asian integration, most importantly with the ASEAN Secretariat6 and with United 
Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (UNESCAP)7, to ensure that 
the Southeast Asia RCSP will complement and reinforce ongoing ASEAN initiatives.  The 
developing member countries involved in the RCSP have also expressed support for its main 
objectives and, most importantly, for the choice of strengthened infrastructure linkages as the 
main focus of assistance. 
 
8.  The TA will accelerate the shift from dialogue to concrete action in support of these 
goals.  The TA will finance preparation of action plans for development of the transport and 
energy sector in the region, rooted in updated projections of supply and demand in these critical 
sectors.  At the decision-making level, a high-level forum envisaged in the TA will identify and 
prioritize strategic objectives in regional cooperation initiatives. At the working level, sector-

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
9.  The TA aims to support background analytical work and stakeholder consultations for 
preparation of the Southeast Asia Regional Department (SERD) RCSP.   
10.  The  main  TA  outputs  are  (i)  expert  studies  in  transport  and  energy  development, 
providing up-to-date analysis and projecting key trends in regional infrastructure demand and 
supply;  and  (ii)  regional  cooperation  projects  and  programs  identified  through  in-country 
consultations on priority sectors.  The findings will be presented at a high-level forum to identify 
emerging challenges and opportunities for regional cooperation in the region. 
11.  The TA framework is in Appendix 1.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The following methodologies and activities are envisaged for the TA with respect to the 
three interrelated components. 
13.  Expert  Studies  and  Action  Plans  on  Regional  Cooperation  Approaches  in 
Transport  and  Energy  Development.    The  TA  will  finance  the  preparation  of  expert 
assessments  and  action  plans  on  supply-and-demand  trends  in  transport  and  energy 
infrastructure in the region, and on the potential for and constraints to regional cooperation in 
these areas. The assessment will be the basis for the policy dialogue between ADB and the 
stakeholders, and provide inputs to the high-level forum.    
14.  Regional  Cooperation  Projects  and  Programs.    The  TA  will  support  in-country 
consultation activities, including sector workshops in transport and energy, to develop priority 
projects in strategic sectors in the next 3-5 years.  
15.  High-Level Forum for Regional Cooperation.  The TA will organize and finance a 
high-level  forum  at  ADB  headquarters  in  Manila,  to  produce  substantive  and  relevant 
recommendations for policy makers who will be ADB’s key partners in implementing the RCSP. 
The forum will invite senior-level (ministerial-rank) policy makers, development practitioners, 
and academic researchers as resource persons. Topics at the forum will include (i) in-depth 
discussion of the energy and transport action plans, and the first steps in launching them; (ii) 
broad review of development challenges and opportunities in Southeast Asia through regional 
cooperation in the context of realization of the AEC in 2020. 
16.  The TA will cover Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, and Singapore. 
Although Brunei Darussalam is not currently an ADB member, it is included in the TA, as its

participation is essential for the TA objective of promoting regional cooperation in Southeast 
Asia.8 A no-objection letter from each of the participating DMCs will be obtained before the TA is 
carried out in each of the DMCs.  
C.  Cost and Financing  
17.  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $370,000  equivalent,  of  which  $350,000  is  in  foreign 
exchange and $20,000 equivalent is in local currency. ADB will finance the entire foreign 
exchange cost on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The TA will cover the costs of 
engaging consulting services (remuneration, per diem, and travel) and preparing reports. The 
TA  will  also  finance  regional  consultation  including  a  high-level  forum  and  in-country 
consultation activities, expert studies of priority sectors, and dissemination of major TA output. 
As it is currently not an ADB member, Brunei Darussalam will finance all direct local costs that 
could be incurred by that country in implementing the TA. Brunei Darussalam will provide an 
estimated $20,000 equivalent in the form of office space, staff support, conference participation, 
and other in-kind contributions.9 The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 
2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  ADB (SERD) will be the Executing Agency for the TA. With the assistance of a team of 
consultants,  ADB  staff  will  work  with  government  agencies  and  business  communities  in 
implementing the TA. Implementation will take 6 months beginning in April 2004 and ending in 
September 2004. The TA requires two international consultants (6 person-months) and one 
domestic consultant (5 person-months). The terms of references for consultants are in Appendix 
3. ADB will recruit the consultant team individually in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants and other arrangements acceptable to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. 
Policy dialogue and consultation will be carried out with public institutions, the private sector, 
and other aid agencies. Government agencies concerned will provide logistic convenience and 
support  including  liaison  with  the  consultant  team  and  assistance  in  accessing  required 
information and data. All procurement of equipment and materials, and service payments under 
the TA will follow ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. 
19.  The consultants will undertake their assignments intermittently during the TA period. The 
draft sector study report should be completed by June 2004, and the final TA report by the end 
of August 2004. In view of the time constraint, advance action in recruiting consultants is 
required to ensure timely completion of the TA. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $350,000 on a grant basis for 
Support to Strategize Regional Cooperation in Southeast Asia, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board. 
                                                 
8  Although Brunei Darussalam is not an ADB member, it is a member of BIMP-EAGA subregional cooperation 
program, which remains a key part of overall strategic concerns in supporting regional cooperation in Southeast 
Asia. 
9  No financial and other support, which originated from the TASF, will be provided to conference participants from 
Brunei Darussalam and procurement of goods and services will only be limited to ADB’s member countries.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Transport Sector Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
1.  The transport sector specialist will prepare a time-bound action plan identifying further 
steps to be taken by governments of ASEAN countries, relevant regional bodies (such as the 
Association of Southeast Asian Nations [ASEAN Secretariat]), and the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) in support of regional cooperation in the transport sector.  The action plan will be based 
on a rigorous assessment and projection of regional transport sector conditions, and will include 
the following tasks: 
(i)  Collect updated information and data on intraregional trade and transport sector, 
including  (a)  trade  flows,  (b)  transport  demand  characteristics,  (c)  transport 
supply characteristics, (d) institutional and regulatory aspects.  
 
(ii)  Assess  the  transport  supply  characteristics  in  the  region  and  adequacy  of 
transport  infrastructure,  transport  services,  and  logistics  systems  for  efficient 
regional trade.  
 
(iii)  Forecast intraregional trade flows and the resulting transport demand under three 
growth scenarios. Based on the assessment made in task (ii), identify potential 
transport-related  problems  that  could  hamper  regional  growth,  including  the 
transport  network  and  coverage,  infrastructure  capacity  constraints,  transport 
service and operation problems, and regulatory and institutional constraints.  
 
(iv)  Identify 3-4 most probable regional cooperation initiatives in the transport sector 
to mitigate the problems identified in task (iii) as case studies. Demonstrate 
economic benefits of regional cooperation in the transport sector by providing a 
sound economic analysis to ensure that the initiatives will achieve maximum 
benefits for society.  
 
(v)  Review the existing transport infrastructure projects and policy initiatives, which 
are relevant to supporting regional cooperation in the transport sector. Assess 
how these plans can support the initiatives identified in task (iv).  
 
(vi)  Prepare a strategy to improve transport sector integration in the region, which will 
include an assessment of prospects and approaches for obtaining private sector 
participation in transport projects in the region. 
 
(vii)  Identify 5–6 highest priority opportunities for ADB to support regional cooperation 
in transport sector development.  These may include possible investments for 
ADB to develop transport linkages within the region, as well as opportunities for 
ADB to promote intraregional investments in the transport sector. 
 
(viii)  Submit the draft action plan to ADB no later than 3 weeks before the high-level 
forum on regional cooperation, for comments and revisions, so that the action 
plan can be circulated to forum participants 2 weeks before the forum.  Present 
key  findings  at  the  forum,  and  in  in-country  consultations  as  decided  in 
consultation with ADB.

B.  Energy Sector Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
2.  The energy sector specialist will prepare a time-bound action plan identifying further 
steps to be taken by governments, relevant regional bodies (such as the ASEAN Secretariat), 
and ADB in support of regional cooperation in the energy sector.  The action plan will be based 
on a rigorous assessment and projection of regional energy sector conditions, and will include 
the following tasks: 
(i)  State the estimated reserves (proven, probable, and possible) or potential of 
each primary energy source (oil, gas, coal, hydroelectricity, geothermal sources, 
nuclear power), for each country in the region. 
 
(ii)  Prepare material balances for each primary energy source for each ASEAN 
country,  showing  current  levels  of  indigenous  production,  import,  indigenous 
consumption  (for  each  major  consumer  sector  including  power,  fertilizer, 
transport, commercial, and residential), and export. 
 
(iii)  Project for a 15-year period the supply of each primary energy source for each 
ASEAN country, based on existing sources of production (developed oil and gas 
fields, and coal, hydroelectric, and geothermal reserves) and planned/anticipated 
capacity additions. 
 
(iv)  Project for a 15-year period consumer demand for each primary energy source, 
for each ASEAN country, based on moderate, medium, and high gross domestic 
product (GDP) growth rate scenarios, and taking into account specific major 
development plans and projects (e.g., additional power generation capacity). 
 
(v)  Project a 15-year period supply-demand gap for each primary energy source for 
each ASEAN country, for the three GDP growth rate scenarios. 
 
(vi)  Review  short-,  medium-,  and  long-term  infrastructure  development  plans 
(covering a 15-year period) in the energy sector, in each ASEAN country, and list 
ongoing and/or approved and/or proposed energy production and/or generation 
and transmission and/or transportation projects. 
 
(vii)  Identify  approved  and  proposed  energy  infrastructure  development  projects 
(ongoing, approved, and proposed) in each ASEAN country, the scope of which 
could be extended to include cross-border energy transfer. 
 
(viii)  Identify other (i.e., not ongoing, approved, or proposed) energy infrastructure 
development projects to promote cross-border energy transfer.    
 
(ix)  Outline  completed  and  ongoing  cross-border  energy  transactions  within  the 
region (including project scope, cost, and financing plan). 
 
(x)  Assess prospects and approaches for obtaining private sector participation in 
cross-border energy projects in the region. 
 
(xi)  Identify 5–6 highest priority opportunities for ADB to support regional cooperation 
in energy sector development.  They may include possible investments for ADB

C.  Development Economist (domestic, recruited in one of the Southeast Asian countries, 
5 person-months) 
3.  The development economist will assume the following responsibilities: 
(i)  assist with organizing and coordinating of in-country consultation activities and  
the  high-level  forum  for  regional  cooperation;  and  perform  other  follow-up 
activities; 
 
(ii)  help prepare project profiles for regional projects; and 
 
(iii)  help implement the proposed TA, including (a) monitoring budget disbursements 
and contract variations, and (b) procuring other inputs. 
 
D.  Resource Persons for High-Level Forum for Regional Cooperation  
4.  Three to four distinguished resource persons will be engaged for the high-level forum for 
regional cooperation. The resource persons, with backgrounds in policy and practice in regional 
cooperation,  are  expected  to  speak  on  and  present  key issues  of  regional cooperation  in 
Southeast Asia. Among the topics would are: 
(i)  strategic challenges and responses for Southeast Asia to accelerate the process 
of regional cooperation and integration, so as to achieve an ASEAN Economic 
Community (AEC) in 2020; 
(ii)  the prospects for infrastructure development (multimodal transport and energy) 
and service facilitation in promoting development and regional cooperation in 
Southeast Asia; and 
(iii)  the  role  that  multilateral  development  institutions  can  play  in  support  of  the 
regional strategic objectives of cooperation and integration.
